author: Daryl Lindsey
title: The ACLU received a record number of online donations after challenging Trump’s #MuslimBan
text:
The ACLU received a record number of online donations after challenging Trump’s #MuslimBan It’s been a good weekend for the American Civil Liberties Union: After they challenged a discriminatory executive order signed by President Donald Trump Friday, the ACLU received $24.1 million online donations. 
That’s six times what it normally receives in a whole year, in case you were wondering. The executive order temporarily banned citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries : Iraq, Iran, Syria, Somalia, Libya, and Yemen from entering the country, even if those citizens were Green Card or Visa holders.
The ACLU challenged the executive order – and won. Signed judge's order. No refugees are going to be immediately deported pic.twitter.com/sbfaG7DBt0 
— ACLU National (@ACLU) January 29, 2017 

This news spurred the wave of donations to the ACLU, with thousands taking to the internet to urge others to donate. Many celebrities, including Judd Apatow, Rosie O’Donnell, and Sia, posted online that they would match fans’ donations up to $100,000.
help our queer & immigrant friends. send me your donation receipts for the @aclu & I will match up to $100K https://t.co/P9zVRH0WH0 #RESIST 
— sia (@Sia) January 28, 2017 

According to CNN, many of the 356,306 people who donated to the ACLU were first-time supporters .
“I spend way more than $25 a month on brunch,” Brooklyn resident Jenn Pollan, 26, told Mic. “It seemed fitting to donate to an organization that is on the front lines of fighting fascism.” #jfkterminal4 #refugeeswelcome #nomuslimban #nomuslimbanjfk 
A photo posted by ACLU (@aclu_nationwide) on Jan 28, 2017 at 2:00pm PST 
The ACLU says it will use the new donations to add to its staff.
